list.title: Important Picnic
list.dek: The longtime Long Beach noise-rock trawlers Gang Wizard's newest album, Important Picnic, might be the best of their 40 or so releases. On previous efforts, their boundlessness has sometimes drifted into tedium, but there's no downtime on this pulse-quickening collection.

list.title: Here and Nowhere Else
list.dek: Cloud Nothings' latest album moves in one direction and at a breakneck pace. Dylan Baldi is simply unwilling or unable to stop writing hook-filled songs, rendering Here and Nowhere Else even more tense and thrillingly conflicted than its predecessor. The band continues to make powerfully utilitarian music for people who don’t seek out this type of music just to be told what to think.

list.title: II: Void Worship
list.dek: The young Rhode Island doom revivalists Pilgrim's second album is more relentless and loaded than its predecessor, even though the duo often forgoes an additional layer of vocals. But their abiding sense of doom remains intact, and they now seem capable of writing around the records from which they learned.

list.title: Teeth Dreams
list.dek: After four good-to-fantastic records, the Hold Steady returned in 2010 with Heaven Is Whenever, a too-sleek, cliche-mottled shrug of a record. From its opening line on, the band's sixth album, Teeth Dreams, tries to position itself as a return to form.

list.title: Dylan's Gospel
list.dek: Over two days in July, 1969, a group recruited by Lou Adler from the L.A. backup-singer circuit recorded churchified versions of 10 familiar Bob Dylan tunes, and the results are way better than they have a right to be. This remastered reissue features liner notes interviewing Adler and vocalists Merry Clayton and Edna Wright.

list.title: The Rite of Spring
list.dek: Musicians will never stop trying to reimagine Stravinsky's savage, gleaming The Rite of Spring, and now the Bad Plus are stepping up to the plate. The jazz trio won acclaim by twisting hard rock and punk songs into their own language, but the Bad Plus just aren't a match for the full blast of Stravinsky's orchestra.

list.title: Out Among the Stars
list.dek: Johnny Cash recorded Out Among the Stars with countrypolitan producer Billy Sherrill in the early 1980s, but the album never saw release at the time. Rescued from the vaults and augmented with new instrumentation, Stars sheds welcome light on a period when Cash kept a low profile.

list.title: III: Beneath Trident's Tomb
list.dek: Twilight features metal heavyweights like Leviathan’s Wrest, Krieg’s Neil Jameson, and the Atlas Moth's Stavros Giannopoulos along with newest member Thurston Moore. On III: Beneath Trident's Tomb, the collective scrapes through black metal and sludge, industrial and noise, post-punk and atmospheric interludes.

list.title: Boy
list.dek: Carla Bozulich has spent decades navigating the art-rock underground through sheer tenacity and a fierce commitment to her own distinctive musical vision. She proclaims her latest solo album, Boy, as her version of a “pop record,” and it's indeed her most approachable album in a while.

list.title: My Krazy Life
list.dek: Compton rapper YG and producer DJ Mustard have forged the type of symbiotic producer-rapper bond that's scarcely been seen on a mainstream field of play since Drake and Noah "40" Shebib. On YG's major-label debut, Mustard’s production and YG’s songwriting have both gone deliciously widescreen.

list.title: Two
list.dek: Unlike almost anything that Tim Kinsella has been involved with, Owls' first LP in nearly 13 years, Two, doesn’t need a preemptive warning about its “challenging” nature. Kinsella's pretty much stopped caring about public perception, which has resulted in some of his most honest and direct music.

list.title: Lavender Country
list.dek: Patrick Haggerty was raised on a dairy farm outside Seattle before the twin shocks of the Stonewall riots and his ejection from the Peace Corps radicalized him. In 1973 he released Lavender Country, widely regarded as the first country record by an openly gay person, in an edition of 1,000. Now that the label Paradise of Bachelors is reissuing the collection, the richness of Haggerty's achievement can be appreciated again.

list.title: Louder Space
list.dek: In just three years, Lamont “Bim” Thomas, who's played drums in V-3, Bassholes, This Moment in Black History, Puffy Aerolas, and others, has cranked out three albums plus EPs and singles as Obnox, pouring his energies into burning-red noise-punk blasts. His newest, the blazing Louder Space, is the first he recorded in a studio.

list.title: IN.RAK.DUST
list.dek: Gang Gang Dance co-founder Tim DeWit's first full-length as Dutch E Germ is his most substantial artistic statement since co-producing GGD's landmark 2008 album Saint Dymphna. Following contributions to a soundtrack for a Baltimore biker documentary and his appearance on Yeezus, IN.RAK.DUST sees him creating a new kind of dub.

list.title: Oksastus
list.dek: Pan Sonic, the Finnish noise duo who split in 2010, recorded this meticulous live effort in 2009 in Kyiv in the Ukraine. It's impossible to frame it without thinking about the impending meltdown of both band and country, cloaking Oksastus in an apocalyptic backdrop.

list.title: By Any Means
list.dek: With his Atlantic debut looming on the horizon and a higher profile than he's ever enjoyed, the Baton Rouge rapper Kevin Gates' newest mixtape is packed with uptempo anthems, chest-pumping bravado, and a 2 Chainz guest spot. The beats here are a little bigger than in the past and have more of a sheen to them.

list.title: Light Divide
list.dek: On Light Divide, Barn Owl multi-instrumentalist Jon Porras moves between drones and keyboard melodies, deep beats and microscopic clicks, foreboding bass and comforting silvery drift. The collection refracts and then reorders moody electronic music, creating more of a mirage than a mere collage.

list.title: Recess
list.dek: Skrillex is a festival-circuit megastar who’s already put an indelible sonic imprint on the early stretch of this decade, but Recess is his first proper album. It's a mix of big-drop dubstep tunes and whatever-works eclecticism, including spots from Chance the Rapper, Diplo, and Michael Angelakos of Passion Pit.

list.title: We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle
list.seoTitle: We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle
list.socialTitle: We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle
list.promoTitle: We Must Rebel/I Hate Myself/Endless Struggle
list.dek: Of all the historic punk and hardcore bands based in Austin in the early 80s—MDC, D.R.I., the Big Boys, the Dicks—Offenders remain the least celebrated. In an effort to rectify this blind spot, 1983’s We Must Rebel, 1985’s Endless Struggle, and the 1984 7” “I Hate Myself”/“Bad Times” have been collected by Southern Lord as a double-LP anthology including beefed-up fidelity. Not that these songs have ever sounded less than staggeringly savage.

list.dek: For the last three decades, Current 93 have been not so much a band as an ever-evolving collective anchored around the complicated vision of David Tibet. I Am the Last of All the Field That Fell not only re-taps past collaborators Antony Hegarty, James Blackshaw, and Nick Cave, but adds John Zorn and Dutch classical pianist Reinier van Houdt, among others, to the fold.

list.dek: On her first full-length, Mirrors in the Sky, London singer-songwriter and producer Lyla Foy’s songs are both lush and low-key, intimate and surprisingly intricate. She layers beats generously but carefully, alternating between buoyant and bittersweet.

list.title: When the Past Arrives
list.dek: The low-key and frequently wonderful project Woo returns with a new collection. Their music is ambient and gentle as new age music can be, but it’s also densely melodic and playful, sounding like Durutti Column as rendered on ukulele, or Cluster if instead of amassing early synthesizers, they collected clarinets.

list.dek: In comparison to 2007's Spirit If..., the Broken Social Scene leader's second solo album doesn't feel like the work of a band. Synth-heavy and prone to slow-building torch songs, Darlings turns out to be a fine showcase for Drew's expressive voice and distinctive obsessions.

list.title: The Drain
list.dek: Psalm Zero is the Brooklyn duo of Andrew Hock (Castevet) and Charlie Looker (Dirty Projectors, Zs, Extra Life). Their debut album, The Drain, offers a mix of metal aggression and industrial wallop, supported in places by Hock’s academic past in free jazz and Looker’s exploration of classical forms.

list.title: Awake
list.dek: On Awake, Scott Hansen, the San Francisco-based visual artist who records colorful techno as Tycho, expands his sound. It's the first Tycho album recorded as a three-piece band, and his previous albums now sound like mere dreams of the luminous world he was trying to create.

list.title: Lost in the Dream
list.dek: If the mesmerizing motorik hum of the War on Drugs' earlier records gave leader Adam Granduciel an outlet to escape his problems, Lost in the Dream is where he pulls a U to survey the emotional wreckage. The result is the band's most lustrous, intricately detailed, and beautifully rendered record to date.

tout.title: Love Is Here To Stay cover art

list.title: Love Is Here To Stay
list.dek: The music Bo Anders Persson made in the late 1960s and early 70s may not have spread wide, but its influence went deep.  Bardo Pond, Acid Mothers Temple, and Sunburned Hand of the Man all owe their smoky trails in part to the paths that Persson’s bands blazed. This set collects some of his early tape-based experiments and ensemble compositions.

list.title: We Got a Love
list.dek: Marcus Lambkin, the Irish producer who records as Shit Robot, is part of a lineage that runs through James Murphy's DFA empire. His new album draws from house, rave, and disco, and includes guest spots from Luke Jenner from the Rapture and Nancy Whang.

list.dek: *The Unsemble—*the eponymous debut album by a trio comprising Alexander Hacke of Einstürzende Neubauten, Duane Denison of the Jesus Lizard, and drummer Brian Kotzur—is neither industrial nor pigfuck. It’s a refined, even contemplative assemblage of instrumental art-rock with a marked lack of shit getting bashed.

list.title: Dean Wareham
list.dek: Like last year’s Emancipated Hearts EP, Dean Wareham’s new self-titled full-length, featuring Papercuts' Jason Quever and My Morning Jacket's Jim James, is less Dean & Britta than Dean to Britta. It’s an album that humorously but honestly explores the tensions that arise in any long-term relationship.

list.title: Heathen
list.dek: Thou have lightened up a bit on their excellent fourth album, their first since 2010’s Summit, without losing their ability to shock and awe. Mixing in clean vocals, acoustic passages, and strings and horns, the 60-plus minute Heathen is the Louisiana sludge/doom band’s most punishing work to date, and yet it's also their most beautiful.

list.title: Abandoned City
list.dek: As Hauschka, Volker Bertelmann writes fairly plain piano music that winds up sounding bewilderingly elaborate. On his new Abandoned City, songs have a clumsy grace, eagerly tripping over themselves as they rush between frolicsome and ominous moods.

list.title: Kindly Bent to Free Us
list.dek: Mixing technical death metal and thundering jazz fusion, the Florida band Cynic's 1993 debut, Focus, still sounds like future music, and their post-reunion LP, 2008’s Traced in Air, thrived on a similarly ambitious mix of power and prowess. But did they really need to make a third record?

list.title: Spectre
list.dek: The Slovenian group Laibach are fundamentally a performance-art project, with a barbed joke they've been repeating for over 30 years: observing how art becomes a tool of totalitarianism, and pushing it as far as it can go in that direction. The title of their new album, Spectre, is an allusion to the opening line of The Communist Manifesto, but it's also a description of the current state of the band.

list.socialTitle: The Soul of All Natural Things
list.promoTitle: The Soul of All Natural Things
list.dek: Linda Perhacs' psychedelic folk album, 1970’s Parallelograms, has persisted over decades, even as she's moved on with her life and copies of it disappeared from print. The followup, arriving 44 years later, was made with several of Perhacs' admirers, including Julia Holter and Nite Jewel's Ramona Gonzalez.

list.title: Yung Archetype EP
list.dek: On his five-song EP Yung Archetype, Nigerian-American songwriter Tunde Olaniran's approach most closely resembles the kitchen-sink genre pastiche of M.I.A. or the silly perceptiveness and electronic experimentation of rap acts like Das Racist. The product is a pitch-perfect mashup of pop-leaning underground music.

list.dek: Relapse Records’ recent signee, the Philadelphia band Nothing, are fronted by ex-Horror Show vocalist Dominic Palermo. Their debut*, Guilty of Everything*, might be unusually heavy dream-pop, billowy alt-rock, or blustery shoegaze, but it is definitely not metal.

list.title: Dreams
list.dek: Informed by dance and electronic music, the Copenhagen pop trio WhoMadeWho's fifth album shuffles through genres while maintaining a cohesive sound. The group features drummer Tomas Barfod, whose 2012 album Salton Sea gave him a kind of name recognition that, at least in the States, the band itself has yet to achieve.

list.title: The Air You Found
list.dek: Empty Flowers retrench the sounds of Slint, Shellac, Girls Against Boys, and Archers of Loaf with a little metal heaviness. This new collection, The Air You Found, offers reworked versions of songs from their two previous LPs by the likes of Justin K Broadrick and members of Tombs, Gorguts, Dysrhythmia, Isis, and Khanate, among others.

list.title: The Power and the Glory
list.dek: Ali Wells, aka Perc, has been making scraping techno bangers, with little rest or deviation, since 2002. His second album, The Power and the Glory, is a bold, roiling collection that feels looser and more chaotic than the rigid constructs he normally works within.

list.title: Warfaring Strangers: Darkscorch Canticles
list.dek: Numero Group's Warfaring Strangers: Darkscorch Canticles is a snapshot of mid-1970s American proto-metal, a loose confederation of groups working mostly in obscurity and isolation that drew on Deep Purple, Uriah Heep, and Black Sabbath. What makes these bands so compelling are their idiosyncratic visions of weird America.

list.title: Pulsing EP
list.dek: While Danish producer Tomas Barfod once delivered a surveying glance at electronic music—floaty vocal electro-pop, playful house, meandering headphone fodder—he sticks to a rigid dichotomy on his new Pulsing. It's sharp, finely sung pop in one hand, and moody instrumental cuts on the other.

list.title: Island Intervals
list.dek: The ambitious subject material on Death Vessel's new Island Intervals could easily be mishandled by someone more precious or novel in his dedication to this aesthetic. But singer Joel Thibodeau’s ear for richly pastoral arrangements make him more than a high-voiced novelty.

list.title: Atlas
list.dek: On Real Estate's rich, sad third album, Atlas, the once-ideal pool party band has turned to soundtracking the cleanup: Everyone's gone, the sky's threatening rain, there are cigarette butts floating in the pool, and we've all gotta work tomorrow. The result is at once their most forlorn record and their most beautiful.

list.title: Wave 1
list.dek: Wave 1, the first new material from Com Truise, aka Seth Haley, in two years, plants itself at the intersection of synth-funk, electro, and fussy 80s computer-pop. On the EP, Haley seems unconcerned with the trends of the day, blissfully mining Reagan-era pop at its most meticulous.

list.title: Home, Like NoPlace Is There
list.dek: The Worcester, Mass., emotive rock band the Hotelier’s sophomore record Home, Like NoPlace Is There, burns with a five-alarm intensity. If there isn’t an intervention or a 3AM phone call that must be answered, a funeral is likely to follow. These emergencies are related with rousing group chants, call-and-response hooks, and collegiate jangle.

list.title: Konstellaatio
list.dek: For 30 years, the Finnish musician Mika Vainio has doggedly explored the outer edges of extreme electronics in a variety of contexts, including his duo Pan Sonic. Konstellaatio, his first full-length in three years under his occasional mononym Ø, is a beautifully somber reverie.

list.title: Manhattan
list.dek: The New York rock quartet Skaters’ debut album about living in Manhattan is titled Manhattan. If the Strokes savvily refashioned NYC iconoclasts like the Velvet Underground and Television as dance-party pop music, Manhattan is what’s become of your head-shop CBGB t-shirt after another 12 years of laundromat visits.

list.title: The Satanist
list.dek: Behemoth's tenth album, The Satanist, is not only the first album by the Polish firebrands in five years, but also their first since frontman Nergal was diagnosed with leukemia in 2010. The collection's vividly rendered, with bright moments that shine outward from the prevailing doom and themes that wind into dense knots and unravel into electrifying leads.

list.title: Present Tense
list.dek: The distinctive sound of Wild Beasts—the dueling voices of Hayden Thorpe and Tom Fleming, a sleek and supple rhythm section, immaculate production—remains on the new Present Tense, but there's a marked shift in lyrical tone. This is on the surface a more domesticated Wild Beasts, but they've lost none of their skill for sharp observation.

list.title: Flash
list.dek: The young Bulgarian rapper DENA's debut album Flash is a small and inviting record that is unfazed—delighted, even—by its own rough edges. She strikes a balance between sounding naive enough to pray to the altar of American rap flash and excess and savvy enough to recognize her own distance from it.

list.title: Digital Resistance
list.dek: The heroic metal band Slough Feg’s excellent ninth album is an exploration of how electronics have turned intelligent people into facile consumers following the orders of a screen. But frontman Mike Scalzi has a lot of fun delivering the lecture: These songs overflow with two-guitar pirouettes and resplendent hooks, dynamic surges and appropriate aggression.

list.title: Voices in a Rented Room
list.dek: Ben Chasny of Six Organs of Admittance and Donovan Quinn of Skygreen Leopards unite on this appealing loose and folky song-based project. Voices in a Rented Room is modestly scaled and simply structured, and Chasny and Quinn are a harmony duo that thrives on mischief and discord.

list.dek: The reissue of Morrissey's third solo studio album comes with a slightly muddy but passable live DVD filmed at California's Shoreline Amphitheatre in October, 1991. list.promoTitle: Someday, the Moon Will Be Gold
list.dek: The 23-year-old Ottawa singer-songwriter Kalle Mattson's third album, Someday, the Moon Will Be Gold, is a document of personal growth set against the backdrop of his mother's death. His sound's never been this fully realized, and he has never drawn himself in such clear, unflinching light.

list.title: Days of the Fallen Sun
list.dek: Enduring metalgaze outfit Junius have been plugging away for ten years, mixing lead singer Joseph E. Martinez's clean-toned vocals with doom-metal guitars and soaring choruses. Their new Days of the Fallen Sun EP includes some of the strongest and most sensuous work they've done.

list.title: Oblique To All Paths
list.dek: After seven years, the international metal quintet Culted have still never met in person. Mixing doom and drone, death metal and sludge, harsh noise and field recordings, their second full-length, Oblique to All Paths, is one of the most willfully eclectic metal records you’ll hear all year.

list.title: Guilt Mirrors
list.dek: It's been seven years since Shocking Pinks' fine 2007 self-titled album and project leader Nick Harte returns with a 160-minute triple album. He still has a rare ability to convey all-consuming sadness, but finding the worthwhile songs in this bloated set takes some work.

list.dek: While indie rock icons Guided by Voices' recent albums—five in two years—have by no means tarnished their legacy, they haven’t exactly expanded upon it either. So it goes with Motivational Jumpsuit, though it's the shortest and strongest of the recent batch.

list.title: As The Stars
list.dek: The Australian group Woods of Desolation, piloted by a musician known simply as D., complete the shift from depressive black metal to something brighter and more refined on their third album, As the Stars. As with Deafheaven, post rock’s builds and joyous crescendos make up a huge part of the compositions, lending a triumphal feel to the overarching despair.

list.title: Blame Confusion
list.dek: Montreal fuzzmerchants Solids operate at one of two speeds: pretty fast, and stupid fast. The duo's debut LP, Blame Confusion, is a blur, 37 minutes of speed limit violation that draws from hardcore blister, dream-punk, and raucous cusp-of-the-1990s indie rock.

list.title: Small Town Heroes
list.dek: Folk outfit Hurray for the Riff Raff's Small Town Heroes borrows liberally from old-time traditions, including Appalachian reels, Big Easy R&B, and Piedmont blues. Yet these songs put a fresh and wily spin on old sounds and ideas, thanks to the formidable presence of singer/songwriter Alynda Lee Segarra.

list.title: Voices
list.dek: On their second full-length, synth-pop outfit Phantogram look to graduate from the subliminal to the substantial. It's a quintessential, 1990s-style major-label debut: more heavy-handed and more expensive-sounding, and also exceedingly self-aware of its mission to deliver the goods at this crucial juncture in the band’s career.

list.title: Dizzy Heights
list.dek: It’s been a dozen years since Neil Finn’s last solo album, but between 2002’s One All and this new Dave Fridmann-produced collection, the New Zealander released three Crowded House records and a handful of other offerings. Rather than retrospective singer-songwriter fare, Dizzy Heights is a collection of sunny psychedelia and woozy pop grandeur.

list.title: Somewhere Else
list.dek: Lydia Loveless' songs are based in country, but she tweaks the forms and formulas of the genre with a bleary belligerence that is, more often than not, directed at herself. Her self-destructive streak makes Somewhere Else both a bracing and a deeply harrowing listen.

list.promoTitle: Burn Your Fire for No Witness
list.dek: Burn Your Fire for No Witness finds the singer-songwriter inhabiting a fuller, louder sound and embracing punchier song structures. The blown-out, full-band energy enlivens Olsen, kindling an intensity that’s always been present in her songs and fanning the flames even higher.

list.title: Est...Folle / Comme à la Radio
list.dek: The curious French chanteuse Brigitte Fontaine’s oeuvre was a touchstone for a number of 90s alt-rock icons like Beck, Sonic Youth, Björk, Jarvis Cocker, and Stereolab. But only with recent reissues of her third and fourth albums—1968’s playful Est…Folle and 1971’s more avant-garde Comme à La Radio (which she recorded with Art Ensemble of Chicago)—is her music domestically available in the US.

list.title: A Place That Doesn't Exist
list.dek: The joy from Willis Earl Beal's free A Place That Doesn’t Exist EP doesn't always come from the music on it, but more from the plot development in his career. The songs rely less on bluesy moans to convey emotion and more on tightly wound tunes.

list.title: †††
list.dek: ††† has been framed as “Chino Moreno’s witch house” project, but what you'll find on the trio's self-titled LP is stadium-status electro-rock akin to Depeche Mode's Songs of Faith and Devotion and Nine Inch Nails. In fact, ††† are supposed to be taken on the same scale as Moreno's other band, the Deftones.

list.title: Real Hair EP
list.dek: Speedy Ortiz's four-song EP keeps runtimes tight and choruses front-and-center, pulling in some of Major Arcana's looser ends without sacrificing the fall-apart charm. The band still worship at the altar of early 90s indie—Pavement, Helium, and Archers of Loaf are their holy trinity—but frontwoman Sadie Dupuis has emerged as a distinctive voice.

list.title: Soak / The Blue Eyes OST
list.dek: Listening to J.G. Thirlwell’s work as Foetus is disorienting. His new record Soak is full-on rock'n'roll, albeit of the theatrical variety, but with a dizzying tone. On the other hand, The Blue Eyes, his soundtrack for a movie of the same name, is eminently clear about its intentions, about the emotions it’s trying to convey, and the response it hopes to evoke.

list.title: You're Gonna Miss It All
list.dek: The Philadelphia emo band Modern Baseball’s second album features a wealth of infectious songs that are both sharply observed and sharply written. You’re Gonna Miss It All mostly concerns itself with wasted time, and it's dense with both hooks and lyrical barbs.

list.title: Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997
list.dek: Hardcore Traxx: Dance Mania Records 1986-1997 is the first-ever compilation to honor Chicago house music's coarse, brilliant, and suddenly trendy prodigal son. Best known for lewd, raw, high-tempo tracks—a style known then and now as ghetto house—the Dance Mania label churned out dozens of classic singles that rarely escaped the Midwest.

list.title: Hotel Valentine
list.dek: On Cibo Matto's new Hotel Valentine, their first in 15 years, the duo displays a more intent purpose than mere let's-get-the-band-back-together restlessness. Seamlessly sampling acid-jazz, Tropicalia, and deep-bass microhouse, Hotel Valentine reveals how many possibilities Cibo Matto have always been open to.

list.title: Little Red
list.dek: The singer's full-length follow-up to her influential 2011 album On a Mission finds her trying to write a new chapter in the story of post-millennial British pop: the artist who exploded out of the London underground and then crafted a sustainable career on her own terms, without relying on newer trends or reliable pop heavyweights.

tout.altText: Image may contain: Human, Person, Clothing, Apparel, Advertisement, and Poster
tout.title: DJ Moondawg Presents: We Invented the Bop cover art

list.title: We Invented the Bop
list.dek: Out of the exhaust from Chicago's drill scene’s fission emerged its antithesis: bop, a chirpy, hyper-saturated romp through major keys and egregious Auto-Tune paired with a goofily swaggy (though no doubt athletic) dance. The We Invented the Bop compilation is the scene’s first official survey on record.

list.title: THRU.U
list.dek: As White Rainbow, Portland's Adam Forkner was a darling of a time when indie rock was just beginning its dalliance with synth music. After a hiatus that lasted several years, he's returned with a self-released collection where he attempts to update his hippietastic sprawl with a more modern template and a newfound sense of irony.

list.title: Instant Alpha
list.dek: Feadz, aka Fabian Pianta, has been a longtime pillar of French house. He emerged in the 90s alongside Mr. Oizo and has put in work for both BPitch and Ed Banger. If his full-length debut, Instant Alpha, highlights anything, it's the limits of how far mere dabbling can get a producer.

list.title: Spiritual Emergency / Mitral Transmission
list.dek: For the last two years, Greg Fox has worked with a dozen projects, but his name has been chased by one thorny apposition: (ex-Liturgy). With two new releases, Guardian Alien’s near-brilliant second LP and a collaboration with jazz pioneer Milford Graves, he may have finally drummed himself past parenthetical suffixation.

list.title: BUM
list.dek: The French trio Cheveu make scrappy garage punk featuring belligerent percussion, textural chaos, synth oddities, and lyrics with absurd narratives and a sense of humor. While still unpredictable, their third album, BUM, is perhaps their most delicately arranged.

list.title: Dunes
list.dek: The Santa Barbara, Calif., quartet Gardens & Villa create synthesizer-heavy naturalistic pop that still gets called “indie rock.” Their second album, Dunes, boasts production from DFA’s Tim Goldsworthy, who ensures they keep things varied and in motion.

list.title: The Unnatural World
list.dek: For all its unrelenting gloom, the Connecticut post-punk outfit Have a Nice Life's six-years-in-the-making second album, The Unnatural World, oozes beauty. Sinuous instead of rigid, bloody instead of embalmed, the album refuses to be frozen in time or place.

list.title: Along the Way
list.dek: A little more than a year ago, Mark McGuire announced his departure from Emeralds. On his kaleidoscopic new LP, Along the Way, he wrote, played, and produced everything, stepping beyond his usual guitar tessellations to add keyboards and mandolin, drum machines and hand drums, vocals and noise. It is a meticulous solo rendering of a full band’s effort.

list.title: Deleted/Fool EP
list.dek: Jerome LOL, previously of LOL Boys, has been identified as a representative of the Seapunk movement, a combination of 90s fashion, internet 1.0 imagery, early aughts R&B, and house music. His Deleted/Fool EP is a collection of R&B tracks punctuated with swirling dancehall rhythms, dulcet California synths, and female guest vocals.

list.title: Worth EP
list.dek: Thomas Arsenault, aka Mas Ysa, is a Montreal-born multi-instrumentalist whose music moves seamlessly between 80s synth-pop, contemporary techno, and indie electronic styles. On his debut EP, he precisely executes his musical ideas and leaves the bloodletting to his lyrics, faintly petulant spasms of romantic denunciation and guilt.

list.title: Angel Guts: Red Classroom
list.dek: Angel Guts: Red Classroom comes bearing the promise of being the most dark and bleak Xiu Xiu album to date. The source for the title of Jamie Stewart's L.A. album is a “Japanese erotic noir” that explores “racialized sex, double suicide, double penetration, criminality, fear of physical harm.”

list.title: VoyAager
list.dek: Given their meticulous ethic, it’s not a complete surprise it’s taken the rhythmically inclined Brooklyn indie-rock act Aa seven years to release a proper follow-up to their 2007 debut, gAame. VoyAager's expertly sculpted 3-D sound world is situated somewhere between the grandiose digi-symphonies of Fuck Buttons and the technicolor throttle of early NIN.

list.title: The Life Stains
list.dek: The Life Stains, the first album from electronic producer DJ Dog Dick, is a full-on expression of Max Eisenberg’s artistic attitude. As the album progresses, sneaky craft bleeds in, and humor and gravity meld into something not so easily pegged.

list.title: High Land, Hard Rain
list.dek: Aztec Camera's 1983 album High Land, Hard Rain showcases frontman Roddy Frame at his most blissfully unaware, creating soulful post-punk with pieces that weren’t neccessarily supposed to fit together. This 30th Anniversary Reissue includes B-sides, remixes and live radio sessions from the period.

list.title: After the Disco
list.dek: The second album from the Shins' James Mercer and producer Brian Burton (aka Danger Mouse) is a more cohesive and full-bodied work than their self-titled 2010 debut. The title of After the Disco suggests that Broken Bells' attention has turned to the dancefloor and that holds true, to a point.
